title: Coat of arms of Central Lithuania
text:
The <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a> that served as the symbol of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Central%20Lithuania">Republic of Central Lithuania</a>. It was established on 12 October 1920 and remained in use until 18 April 1922, when the state ceased to exist.
Design.
The coat of arms was officially defined as an <a href="Eagle%20%28heraldry%29">eagle</a> and <a href="Pahonia">Pahonia</a> (a knight on a horse) in the <a href="Escutcheon%20%28heraldry%29">escutcheon</a>. It consists of 2 <a href="Charge%20%28heraldry%29">charges</a> set next to each other. On the right is a silver (white) eagle wearinga crown, and on the left, a silver (white) <a href="Pahonia">Pahonia</a>, a charge, that consists of a <a href="knight">knight</a> with a sword in his right hand, and a shield with the <a href="Cross%20of%20Lorraine">Cross of Lorraine</a> in his left hand, that is sitting on a jumping horse. Both charges are placed within the red escutcheon with a silver (white) edge.
 Its design referred to the coat of arms used by the <a href="Polish%20National%20Government%20%28November%20Uprising%29">Polish National Government</a> during the <a href="November%20Uprising">November Uprising</a>, in 1831.
History.
The coat of arms was established as the symbol of the state, on 12 November 1920, in the Decree No. 1 of the Chief-in-command of the Army of Central Lithuania. The coat of arms stopped being used after the Republic of Central Lithuania was incorporated into <a href="Second%20Polish%20Republic">Poland</a> on 18 April 1922.
